question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The polynomial $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r.$  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$
inference:
Let $P(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$.
Since $P(x)$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$, we can write
$x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r = (x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1)(x^6 + ax^3 + b)$.
Expanding the right side, we get
\begin{align*} x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r &= x^9 + ax^6 + bx^3 - 3x^8 - 3ax^5 - 3bx^2 + 4x^7 + 4ax^4 + 4bx - x^6 - ax^3 - b \\ &= x^9 + (a-3)x^8 + (4-3a)x^7 + (-1+a-3b)x^6 + (4a+b-a)x^5 + (-3b+4b)x^4 + (4-a)x^3 + (-b)x^2 + 4bx - b\end{align*}
Comparing the coefficients of the powers of $x$, we have
\begin{align*}a - 3 &= 0 \\ 4 - 3a &= 0 \\ -1 + a - 3b &= p \\ 4a + b - a &= 0 \\ -3b + 4b &= q \\ 4 - a &= 0 \\ -b &= r\end{align*}
From the equations, we get $a = 3$, $4 - 3a = 0 \implies a = \frac{4}{3}$, which is a contradiction.
Thus $a = 3$ and $4 - 3(3) = -5 \neq 0$.
Let $a = 3$, then $4 - 3a = 4 - 9 = -5 \neq 0$, which is a contradiction.
Let $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1 = 0$. Let $x^3 = 3x^2 - 4x + 1$.
Then $x^6 = (3x^2 - 4x + 1)^2 = 9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1$.
Also $x^9 = (3x^2 - 4x + 1)(x^6)$.
$x^6 = 9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1$.
$x^9 = (3x^2 - 4x + 1)(9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1)$.
Dividing $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$ by $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$, we get $x^6 + 3x^3 + 1$.
If $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1 = 0$, then $x^3 = 3x^2 - 4x + 1$.
Then $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r = (x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1)(x^6 + ax^3 + b)$.
$x^6 + 3x^3 + 1 = (x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1)(x^3 + 3x^2 + 1)$.
$p = 3$, $q = 1$, $r = -1$.
$(p, q, r) = (3, 1, -1).$
Final Answer: $\boxed{(3, 1, -1)}$
ground_truth:
Let $\alpha$ be a root of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1.$  Then
\[\alpha^4 = 3 \alpha^3 - 4 \alpha^2 + \alpha = 3 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) - 4 \alpha^2 + \alpha = 5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3.\]Hence,
\begin{align*}
\alpha^6 &= (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1)^2 \\
&= 9 \alpha^4 - 24 \alpha^3 + 22 \alpha^2 - 8 \alpha + 1 \\
&= 9 (5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3) - 24 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + 22 \alpha^2 - 8 \alpha + 1 \\
&= -5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4,
\end{align*}and
\begin{align*}
\alpha^9 &= \alpha^3 \cdot \alpha^6 \\
&= (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1)(-5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4) \\
&= -15 \alpha^4 - 13 \alpha^3 + 51 \alpha^2 - 27 \alpha + 4 \\
&= -15 (5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3) - 13 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + 51 \alpha^2 - 27 \alpha + 4 \\
&= -63 \alpha^2 + 190 \alpha - 54.
\end{align*}Then
\begin{align*}
\alpha^9 + p \alpha^6 + q \alpha^3 + r &= (-63 \alpha^2 + 190 \alpha - 54) + p (-5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4) + q (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + r \\
&= (-5p + 3q - 63) \alpha^2 + (-11p - 4q + 190) \alpha + (4p + q + r - 54).
\end{align*}We want this to reduce to 0, so we set
\begin{align*}
-5p + 3q &= 63, \\
11p + 4q &= 190, \\
4p + q + r &= 54.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(6,31,-1)}.$   For these values, $\alpha^9 + p \alpha^6 + q \alpha^3 + r$ reduces to 0 for any root $\alpha$ of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1,$ so $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$ will be divisible by $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1.$

Comparing the coefficients of the powers of $x$, we have
\begin{align*}a - 3 &= 0 \\ 4 - 3a &= 0 \\ -1 + a - 3b &= p \\ 4a + b - a &= 0 \\ -3b + 4b &= q \\ 4 - a &= 0 \\ -b &= r\end{align*}
From the equations, we get $a = 3$, $4 - 3a = 0 \implies a = \frac{4}{3}$, which is a contradiction.
Thus $a = 3$ and $4 - 3(3) = -5 \neq 0$.
Let $a = 3$, then $4 - 3a = 4 - 9 = -5 \neq 0$, which is a contradiction.

Then $x^6 = (3x^2 - 4x + 1)^2 = 9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1$.

$x^6 = 9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1$.
$x^9 = (3x^2 - 4x + 1)(9x^4 - 24x^3 + 26x^2 - 8x + 1)$.

$x^6 + 3x^3 + 1 = (x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1)(x^3 + 3x^2 + 1)$.
$p = 3$, $q = 1$, $r = -1$.
$(p, q, r) = (3, 1, -1).$
Final Answer: $\boxed{(3, 1, -1)}$

ground_truth:
Let $\alpha$ be a root of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1.$  Then
\[\alpha^4 = 3 \alpha^3 - 4 \alpha^2 + \alpha = 3 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) - 4 \alpha^2 + \alpha = 5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3.\]Hence,
\begin{align*}
\alpha^6 &= (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1)^2 \\
&= 9 \alpha^4 - 24 \alpha^3 + 22 \alpha^2 - 8 \alpha + 1 \\
&= 9 (5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3) - 24 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + 22 \alpha^2 - 8 \alpha + 1 \\
&= -5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4,
\end{align*}and
\begin{align*}
\alpha^9 &= \alpha^3 \cdot \alpha^6 \\
&= (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1)(-5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4) \\
&= -15 \alpha^4 - 13 \alpha^3 + 51 \alpha^2 - 27 \alpha + 4 \\
&= -15 (5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 3) - 13 (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + 51 \alpha^2 - 27 \alpha + 4 \\
&= -63 \alpha^2 + 190 \alpha - 54.
\end{align*}Then
\begin{align*}
\alpha^9 + p \alpha^6 + q \alpha^3 + r &= (-63 \alpha^2 + 190 \alpha - 54) + p (-5 \alpha^2 - 11 \alpha + 4) + q (3 \alpha^2 - 4 \alpha + 1) + r \\
&= (-5p + 3q - 63) \alpha^2 + (-11p - 4q + 190) \alpha + (4p + q + r - 54).
\end{align*}We want this to reduce to 0, so we set
\begin{align*}
-5p + 3q &= 63, \\
11p + 4q &= 190, \\
4p + q + r &= 54.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(6,31,-1)}.$   For these values, $\alpha^9 + p \alpha^6 + q \alpha^3 + r$ reduces to 0 for any root $\alpha$ of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1,$ so $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$ will be divisible by $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1.$
